speaker: Frasier
text: Ah, Niles.

speaker: Niles
text: Hello.  Is it just me, or are the sidewalk Santas getting pushy?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, tomorrow is Christmas.  I suppose they might be expecting a little downturn after that.

speaker: Niles
text: [_to waitress_] Cappuccino, please. [_to Frasier_] So?  When does Frederick arrive?

speaker: Frasier
text: In six hours and twenty-one minutes.  Not that I'm the least bit excited.

speaker: Niles
text: Yes, I'm sure he's excited too.  First Christmas at daddy's. I imagine he has visions of sugarplums dancing through his head.

speaker: Frasier
text: No, Lilith doesn't allow sweets, he's probably got visions of bran.

speaker: Niles
text: Well, I've got my own reasons to celebrate.  Maris and I may be together again, by the new year.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_supportively_] Oh, really Niles?

speaker: Niles
text: Yep, yeah.  I called this morning to arrange the delivery of her Christmas gift, and she said the only gift she'd accept from me was an abject apology.

speaker: Frasier
text: Going to cave into her, aren't you?

speaker: Niles
text: _Au contraire_.  I told her I was not about to apologise, and from that point on, the respect in her voice came through loud and clear.  No small feat, considering at the time she was speaking at the time through the hole in her massage table.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, hi Roz.

speaker: Roz
text: Hey. [_to waitress_] Double espresso, please.  This last-minute Christmas shopping is killing me.  I never know what to give the men in my life.

speaker: Frasier
text: Since when?

speaker: Roz
text: Ha, ha.  Funny man.

speaker: Niles
text: [_to waitress, handing over his credit card_] Excuse me, I'll take care of this.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, thank you Niles.

speaker: Roz
text: What's new, Niles?

speaker: Niles
text: I have been keeping it under wraps but, Maris and I have separated.

speaker: Roz
text: [_feigning shock, badly_] Oh, my God!  I had no idea.  I can't believe no-one told me.  This is such a surprise!

speaker: Frasier
text: [_can stand no more_] That's enough, Talulah.  You're not fooling anyone.

speaker: Waitress
text: I'm sorry sir, your card didn't clear.  I have to do this.

speaker: Niles
text: Wait, wait!  What are you doing?

speaker: Waitress
text: [_hands the pieces to Niles_] The computer said "credit cancelled by order of co-signatory."

speaker: Frasier
text: Maris has cancelled your credit card.

speaker: Roz
text: Whoa, Merry Christmas!

speaker: Waitress
text: Would you care to use a different one?

speaker: Niles
text: There's no point, they're all in her name. [_he gets his phone and dials a number_] I'm calling her right now and demanding the restoration of my credit card.  And my bank accounts. [_realizes the phone is dead_] And my phone service! _FADE OUT  Scene Two - KACL Frasier is taking a call.  There is an office party going on outside the booth._

speaker: Bob
text: [_v.o._] Doc, I'm at the airport, and I'm having a lot of trouble getting on the plane.

speaker: Frasier
text: Now Bob, statistics prove that we're safer in the air than on the ground.

speaker: Bob
text: That-that's not it.  I'm supposed to be flying home to Newark for Christmas, but the flight the next gate over has a flight to Maui.  I'm telling you, it's calling me, Doc.

speaker: Frasier
text: Why are you hesitant to go home?

speaker: Bob
text: Because it's the same thing every year.  I travel three thousand miles to sit down at the dinner table with my family, and what do we talk about?  What's going on in out lives?  No.  Our hopes and dreams?  No.  We talk about the turkey.  "Boy, that's quite a bird."  "Twenty-four pounder." "What time did you have to get up to put that in the oven, Ange?"

speaker: Frasier
text: "Oh boy, that's moist.  You must have been basting that bird all day."

speaker: Roz
text: "Are those walnuts in the stuffing?"

speaker: Frasier
text: "Oh god, I forgot to put the rolls in the oven."  I guess what I'm trying to say, Bob, is that we're all in the same gravy boat.  But you see, the important thing is that we spend time with our loved ones.  Just think how you'd feel if you woke up tomorrow morning six thousand miles away from your home.

speaker: Bob
text: Well, I tell ya, that really puts it in perspective, doc. I got a plane to catch.

speaker: Frasier
text: _Mele Keleke Maka_ , Bob.  We'll be right back after these messages.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, Roz.  What did they say, what did they say?

speaker: Roz
text: Oh, relax.  Frederick's flight is still on time, he'll be here in less than three hours.  Oh, and the florist called, you can pick up your wreath on the way home.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, fabulous.  You know, every year Dad puts that kitschy creature with the lightbulb nose on the door. _Bulldog enters, his arm in a sling.  He's wearing an elf's hat with a sprig of mistletoe hanging from a spring over his head._

speaker: Bulldog
text: Hey, great party.  Best one ever, thanks to me.  I hired a stripper!  Doc, you will never guess what her name is - Candy Kane.

speaker: Frasier
text: What are the odds?

speaker: Gil
text: For those of you who have not yet sampled the punch, here is my capsule review: vile bouquet, unwholesome colour, ghastly taste - and a kick that is simply heaven.

speaker: Roz
text: [_trying to get rid of Bulldog and Gil_] OK, 30 seconds, Frasier. [_to Gil and Bulldog_] Out!

speaker: Frasier
text: All right people, out, out, please.

speaker: Bulldog
text: [_indicating the mistletoe_] Hey, Roz.  You know what's over my head?

speaker: Roz
text: Almost any clever remark? [_Gil bursts out laughing_]

speaker: Bulldog
text: What's she mean by that?

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, listen Roz.  I know you've got a plane to catch and the traffic to the airport is probably very bad, so in the spirit of the Christmas season, why don't you just take off early, hmm?

speaker: Roz
text: You're going to read one of your inspirational Christmas fables again, aren't you?

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, I am.  Be a lot easier without you sitting over there sticking your finger in your throat.

speaker: Roz
text: Right.  Merry Christmas. [_They kiss and hug_]

speaker: Frasier
text: Merry Christmas, Roz.

speaker: Roz
text: Say "Hi" to Frederick.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, and say "Hi" to your mom for me.

speaker: Roz
text: Will do.  _She leaves.  Frasier turns on the mike and takes a script out of his briefcase._

speaker: Frasier
text: Hi, we're back.  As most of my faithful listeners know, every year I compose a parable that I hope will illuminate the spirit of the Christmas season.

speaker: Frasier
text: So without any further ado, I give you "The Story of Olaf, the lonely little goatherd." _He plays a tape of barnyard noises.  Bulldog and Gil sneak in via Roz's booth._

speaker: Frasier
text: "Once upon a time, there lived a lonely little goatherd. He had no family, and no playthings, so to amuse himself, one day he carved a little wooden flute." _Bulldog and Gil come into Frasier's booth.  They proceed to garnish him in tinsel and lights.  He ignores them._

speaker: Frasier
text: "A flute that he used to play during the long, lonely evenings.  And the tune it made was very lovely, and all the people in the village below could hear the pure, glorious sound..." [_hits cough button; to Bulldog_] This is all very amusing, but nothing you can do is going to distract me! _Bulldog plugs in the lights, making Frasier glow.  They laugh. Frasier lets go of the button.  Gil leaves the booth._

speaker: Frasier
text: "One day, the son of a wealthy merchant heard the music, and while that boy had all the toys in the world, he was jealous of this little goatherd's flute."

speaker: Frasier
text: "So one dark- [_blows out Bulldog's lighter_] -night, one dark- [_blows it out again_] -windy night..."

speaker: Frasier
text: "The merchant's son stole his precious instrument, but when he took that flute home, he couldn't make it play.  So he smashed the flute to bits."  _Bulldog and Gil return with Candy, a woman unrecognizable as such under a Santa costume and thick white beard._

speaker: Frasier
text: "When the little goatherd came down the mountain the next day, and saw his flute was broken..."

speaker: Frasier
text: YIKES! [_starts ad-libbing_] "He might have said that..." _As he hastily tries to reach the end, Candy begins to dance nearer to him, taking off her glasses and whipping off the beard with a flourish._

speaker: Frasier
text: "But instead he forgave the merchant's son.  And the wealthy merchant adopted the little goatherd, and..."

speaker: Frasier
text: OH, MAMA! -- "he said, upon meeting the merchant's wife..." _Candy throws off her Santa hat and white wig, revealing a mane of blond hair, and starts kissing Frasier's cheeks and playing with the tinsel on his head._

speaker: Frasier
text: "And somewhere along the way, he learned the true meaning of Christmas."  This is Dr. Frasier Crane, wishing you a truly blessed and forgiving holiday. _He goes off the air.  With magisterial dignity, he stands up and removes the tinsel and lights from his head.  As he packs his briefcase, Gil and Bulldog look disappointed, while Candy sits sulkily on the edge of the console._

speaker: Frasier
text: There now, you see?  Nice try.  Miss Kane's delightful performance aside, this just proves the power of my message cannot be stayed.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh for God's sakes, what am I, a robot? _He goes back to Candy and kisses her passionately, bowing her over the console.  Gil and Bulldog laugh._

speaker: Frasier
text: And to all a good night. [_leaves_] **IF I ONLY HAD A BRAIN**  _Scene Three - Hallway Frasier emerges from the lift with his wreath to meet his father hanging Rudolph from the door._

speaker: Frasier
text: Hi, Dad.  Ah, [_taking Rudolph down_] I'm going to put this wreath up here.

speaker: Martin
text: What's the matter with Rudolph?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well Dad, you know, I just think that Christmas decorations should be understated and tasteful.

speaker: Martin
text: Boy, I can't get one thing that I want.

speaker: Frasier
text: Dad, I'm sorry, but if I gave you one thing, God knows where it might lead. _They enter the apartment.  Reset to: Living Room Martin leads Frasier in.  Frasier stops dead.  It is full of the most garish decorations ever.  Think of Hamley's toy store, at Christmas. Frasier is nearly in tears._

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, God... it's my childhood Christmases all over again.  Only now Mom isn't here to say, "Shut up, you'll hurt his feelings."

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, don't be such a Grinch.

speaker: Santa
text: Ho, Ho, Ho!

speaker: Martin
text: It works when you step on the mat. [_steps on it_]

speaker: Santa
text: Ho, Ho, Ho!

speaker: Martin
text: It can say "Ho, Ho, Ho", "Merry Christmas", or "Happy Holidays."

speaker: Frasier
text: Yeah, well I hope it can say "Geronimo" because I'm going to throw him off the balcony!

speaker: Martin
text: Well, I don't care what you think, it's not for you, it's for Frederick.

speaker: Frasier
text: God, I suppose you're right, Dad.  I used to love this stuff when I was six.  By the time I was seven I started to have questions.  When I was eight I started spending a lot more time at the Bernsteins.

speaker: Daphne
text: Well, I'm off to Joe's parents' house.

speaker: Frasier
text: I see you've been busy in the kitchen.

speaker: Daphne
text: Yes.  I'm bringing Grammy Moon's famous plum duff.  It's a still flour pudding boiled in a cloth bag.

speaker: Martin
text: Who gets to lick the bag?

speaker: Daphne
text: No.  You see, Grammy Moon had a secret ingredient.  She'd soak it for hours in rum, then ignite it in a blinding flash. As soon as she came out of the kitchen with no eyebrows, we knew dessert was ready. [_She moves towards the door, stepping over the Santa mat_] You know, to this day the smell of burning hair puts me in the holiday spirit.  Bye, Merry Christmas. [_she leaves_]

speaker: Frasier
text: Merry Christmas.

speaker: Martin
text: You know, someone's got to go back down to the storeroom, there's still something missing.

speaker: Frasier
text: You must be kidding, Dad.  My God, this place couldn't look any more ludicrous. _Eddie comes in.  He's wearing a Santa hat and bib.  The doorbell chimes. Frasier goes to answer it._

speaker: Martin
text: Once I saw how those white hairs on his chin looked like a beard, the rest of the idea just fell into place.

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles.

speaker: Niles
text: Hello, Frasier...

speaker: Niles
text: I know, I know - "Shut up, we'll hurt his feelings."

speaker: Frasier
text: So, Niles, did you have a discussion with Maris?

speaker: Niles
text: No, but! - I had an epiphany.  I realised, cutting off my funds is Maris's way of saying, "I love you!"

speaker: Niles
text: She always uses money to get what she wants; ergo, this is proof she wants _me_ back!  What do you think? [_walks past Santa_]

speaker: Santa
text: Ho, Ho, Ho!

speaker: Frasier
text: I think Santa's said it all for us.

speaker: Niles
text: Dad, you have to get out more.  You've started doing old lady things.

speaker: Martin
text: It's for Frederick!

speaker: Niles
text: [_humouring him_] Oh, of course it is.  Oh, that reminds me, I don't want to impose, but may I ride with you to the airport to pick up Frederick?

speaker: Frasier
text: Of course you may, Niles. [_picks up a large box_] Just have to wrap up his presents first.

speaker: Martin
text: So what did you get Freddie?

speaker: Frasier
text: [_opening box_] Well actually dad, I ordered him the toy catalogue, from the special section called "Gifts for the Gifted."  I got him the junior astronomy set, and the geology lab - oh, and a fabulous thing called the "Living Brain."  You get to paint each lobe a different colour, then you stuff it inside the Living Skull.

speaker: Martin
text: Hey, you know what kids really like?  They've been advertising it like crazy on TV.  It's great.  The Outlaw Laser Robo Geek. Its head lights up and it shoots death rays out of its eyes. [_Frasier glowers at him_] Yeah.  A little like that.

speaker: Frasier
text: Listen Dad, I think I know what Frederick likes.  He's precocious, he needs to be challenged.

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, challenge him the other 364 days.  One day out of the year, indulge him.  Let him be a kid.

speaker: Frasier
text: Dad, I'm sorry, if Frederick's anything like me, the kind of toys he'll like to play with are... [_He looks in the box_] A kitchen set, a dollhouse and three kinds of Barbies! [_he grabs the delivery note_] This is for a Franklin Crane from Kenibunkport.  God, you realise what this means?!

speaker: Niles
text: Yes.  The Cranes of Maine have got your "Living Brain."

speaker: Frasier
text: No.  It means I don't have anything for Freddie. [_gets his coat_] God, I wanted everything to be so perfect.  Now he's going to have a horrible Christmas.

speaker: Martin
text: It's all right, listen, it's OK.  There's a big toy store in the mall.  They're open late tonight.  Just don't worry about it.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, that's easy for you to say, Dad.

speaker: Frasier
text: My God, it's Christmas Eve, the gifts I ordered are three thousand miles away, my son is due in an hour, and on top of it all I have to go to a mall!

speaker: Santa
text: Ho, Ho, Ho!

speaker: Niles
text: [_as Frasier turns_] Oh, don't look at me, he said it.  _END OF ACT ONE  ACT TWO_ **A MALL AND THE NIGHT VISITORS**  _Scene Four - A Toy Shop in the Mall Frasier and Niles enter.  They can barely move through the crowd._

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles, customers are marauding through here like a pack of feral dogs.  Did you see that woman?  She practically knocked me over on her way to the escalator.

speaker: Niles
text: Well, how about that woman near the cosmetics counter who tried to mace me?

speaker: Frasier
text: That was a cologne sample, Niles.  That's what they do. Now listen, we've got five minutes.  We've got to find a sales clerk.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh well, good luck.

speaker: Frasier
text: All right, we'd better find something ourselves, I guess.  _They start to browse.  Niles picks up a strange-looking red helmet with comedy goggles on it._

speaker: Niles
text: Well hey, hey.  This looks amusing.

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles, may I remind you we're looking for something educational?

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, oh, oh, oh, it has buttons.  _He starts playing with the controls.  A red light on top of the helmet lights up and starts rotating._

speaker: Niles
text: What's it doing?

speaker: Frasier
text: It's flashing.  Niles, please remember that Freddie tested in the highest percentile for cognitive skills and deductive reasoning.

speaker: Niles
text: What's it doing now?

speaker: Frasier
text: It's beeping, for God's sake!  And as much as I'd like to inflict this on Lilith, I'm looking for fast and educational, all right?  _Niles presses another button, and a jet of water from the helmet soaks Frasier._

speaker: Niles
text: [_laughing_] I wonder what else it does?

speaker: Frasier
text: Let's see if it protects your head!  _He whacks Niles round the side of his head.  As Niles gets up, something else catches his eye._

speaker: Niles
text: Ooh, here's something.  Look at this, look at this.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, God.

speaker: Niles
text: It's called "Ecto Goo." [_he picks up some green slime_]

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh well, that sounds vaguely scientific, but what could he possibly learn from that?

speaker: Niles
text: [_who's having trouble controlling the goo_] Well, for starters, he can learn never to wear Armani to a toy store. [_finally manages to drop the stuff_]

speaker: Frasier
text: Let's see, I'll just have to remember what I ordered from the catalogue and look for that.  First, the "Living Brain."

speaker: Kid
text: [_who's been standing beside Frasier_] Living Brain?  What kind of dork wants that?

speaker: Frasier
text: With any luck, the kind of dork who'll be operating on your prostate someday.

speaker: Niles
text: Frasier, Frasier, Frasier. [_points to top shelf_] Look, look, look, there it is.  It's up on the shelf, it's up on the shelf.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, marvelous. [_climbs up to get it_]

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, Lord.  It's covered with dust.

speaker: Frasier
text: The brain is dusty.  Could there be a clearer metaphor? [_the box is empty_] Oh, Lord.  There's nothing in it.

speaker: Woman
text: Can I have it? [_takes the box_]

speaker: Frasier
text: It's an empty box, Ma'am.

speaker: Woman
text: I know, but I can put my son's Robo Geek in it.  You know how scared he'll be when he thinks he's getting something this nerdy?

speaker: Frasier
text: [_to Niles_] Oh God, this is hopeless.  We'll never find anything for Frederick.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, Frasier.  Just give him a cheque.

speaker: Frasier
text: But Niles, you can't give a cheque to a child.

speaker: Niles
text: That's what I'm giving him.  It has a stagecoach on it.

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles, Maris cancelled your account.

speaker: Niles
text: [_realising_] Damn!

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, look.  Look at that man's bag.  "Young Minds." [_to man_] Sir, excuse me, is this store [_indicating bag_] in the mall?

speaker: Man
text: Yeah.

speaker: Frasier
text: And it's educational toys?

speaker: Man
text: Mmm-hmm, nothing but.  It's just a couple of doors down.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes!  Petunia, there is a Santa Claus.

speaker: Man
text: No, they closed a half hour ago.

speaker: Frasier
text: Damn. [_going through the items in the bag_] Look, this is perfect, look a chemistry lab, and a picture puzzle and... [_to man_] You know, my son comes in, in half an hour and I've absolutely nothing for him.

speaker: Niles
text: [_checking watch_] He'll be in, in 22 minutes if he picks up a good tailwind.

speaker: Man
text: You ahh, you really need this stuff bad, don't you?

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, you have no idea, it would save my life.

speaker: Man
text: I'll tell you what.  Seeing as how it's Christmas...

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, God bless you, sir.

speaker: Man
text: A thousand bucks.

speaker: Frasier
text: What?!  A thousand bucks?

speaker: Man
text: Hey, take it or leave it.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, I mean, there's just no more than a hundred dollars worth of things here.

speaker: Niles
text: "Ladies and gentlemen, we're beginning our descent into Seattle airport."

speaker: Man
text: I'm just trying to do you a favour here.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, it's some favour.

speaker: Niles
text: "Please make sure your tables and seats are in their full and upright position."

speaker: Frasier
text: Shut up, Niles!  All right, all right, lets see what I've got here. [_goes through pockets looking for money_] All right, I've got, ahh... Here's three hundred dollars.  Would you- would you accept a personal cheque for the rest?

speaker: Man
text: Hey, it's Christmas.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, bless you, bless you so much.  Very well, thank you. Niles, give the man a cheque. _FADE TO:  Scene Five - Frasier's apartment. Martin is there.  Frasier comes in from the bedrooms._

speaker: Martin
text: Where's Freddie?

speaker: Frasier
text: Putting on his pajamas.  Told me he would come in and say goodnight after he brushes his teeth.

speaker: Martin
text: So how'd you do?

speaker: Frasier
text: [_puting Frederick's presents under the tree_] Well, I didn't get exactly what I'd ordered, but I think I did all right. I got him a microscope, a chemistry set, and a five thousand piece puzzle of the Great Wall of China.

speaker: Martin
text: Well, maybe he'll have fun with the boxes.

speaker: Niles
text: Dad, here you go, this is the last box from the storeroom. [_puts box on coffee table_]

speaker: Martin
text: Great. _Niles pulls out a truly weird item: a pair of fake legs encased in red pants and ending in black boots._

speaker: Niles
text: Now, was this what you were looking for?

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, yeah.  Santa's legs for the chimney, you remember these babies?

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, yes.  Inspired some spectacular Christmas nightmares the year I found them under your bed. _While Martin sticks the legs into the chimney, Niles finds a small box in the bottom of the big one and opens it._

speaker: Niles
text: Frasier, isn't this the  smoking jacket you gave Dad a few years back?

speaker: Martin
text: What?  Hey... [_feigning innocence_] How did that get in there?

speaker: Frasier
text: [_looking through box_] Dad, these are all of the gifts I've given you for the last six years.

speaker: Martin
text: Hey, c'mon now, shut the- put 'em back.  Close the box, will ya?

speaker: Frasier
text: Dad, look at this.  My God, they're still in the original boxes, never been worn.

speaker: Martin
text: Sure they have.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, yeah. [_showing him a tie_] This one still has the tags on it.

speaker: Martin
text: Look, this isn't the kind of conversation we should be having on Christmas eve.

speaker: Frasier
text: No, Dad?  Well, what was it you wanted to say?

speaker: Martin
text: Well, you know Frasier, you're always giving people things you think they should like, instead of things that they really like.  I mean, come on - [_picks up the smoking jacket_] In your entire life, have you ever seen me wear anything like that?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, no.  I thought you might like a change.

speaker: Martin
text: Well, it's like when you were a kid, remember?  I wanted you to love baseball.  I wanted to get you a bat, glove, everything, for Christmas.  But you had your mind set on a microscope, so that's what I got you.

speaker: Niles
text: And then when Dad took us to a game, you spent the whole time looking for rodent hairs in your hot-dog.

speaker: Martin
text: I'm just saying Christmas isn't the time you try to mold somebody, which is what you're trying to do with Frederick.

speaker: Frasier
text: I think I know what's good for my own son.

speaker: Frederick
text: I brushed my teeth, Daddy.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, that's my boy.  Come on. [_he picks Frederick up_]

speaker: Frederick
text: _Bonsoir_ , Uncle Niles.

speaker: Niles
text: _Et toi aussi._

speaker: Martin
text: Hey, you'd better get to sleep, or Santa won't come.

speaker: Frederick
text: OK.  I know just what Santa's bringing me this year, Dad.

speaker: Martin
text: [_aside_] I bet you don't.

speaker: Frederick
text: Yes I do too.  It's an Outlaw Laser Robo Geek.

speaker: Frasier
text: What makes you think that?

speaker: Frederick
text: Because I asked Santa for it in my letter.  They are sooo cool.

speaker: Frasier
text: Ahh, listen ahh, Frederick, there's erm... [_Frederick runs towards the bedroom_] Frederick, where are you going?

speaker: Frederick
text: I'm going to make myself fall asleep right away, so the next thing I know, it'll be morning.  Goodnight, Daddy.

speaker: Frasier
text: I'll come in and tuck you in, in a minute.

speaker: Frederick
text: Goodnight, Grandpa.  Goodnight, Uncle Niles.

speaker: Martin
text: Goodnight.

speaker: Niles
text: Goodnight, Frederick.  I'm going to go home and go to bed too.

speaker: Frederick
text: I hope Aunt Maris comes out of her coma.

speaker: Niles
text: He asked where she was, I thought the truth would just upset him.  I'll see you in the morning.  Merry Christmas.

speaker: Martin
text: See you tomorrow.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, this is turning out to be quite a Christmas.

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, it's going to be fine.

speaker: Frasier
text: Done it again.  Gotten everyone the wrong gifts.  What is it about me? [_getting present from under tree_] Well, here, you might as well open your gift now.  No reason for everyone to be disappointed tomorrow.

speaker: Martin
text: Hey, I'm sure I'm gonna love it. [_he opens the gift_]

speaker: Frasier
text: I doubt it.  Not exactly my night.

speaker: Martin
text: Hey!  A robe!  Great, I love it!

speaker: Frasier
text: No, you don't.  It's not a robe, it's a dressing gown. Noel Coward would love it, but it's not you.

speaker: Martin
text: [_putting it on_] Hey, I love Noel Coward!

speaker: Frasier
text: Dad, you're overcompensating.

speaker: Martin
text: Some people are hard to buy for, I'm sorry.  But, you know, you are too, I never know what to get you.  Here. [_puts present in front of Frasier_] You might as well open this now.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_opening present_] Yeah.  Guess it was easier when I was small.  'Cause kids always know what they want, don't they?

speaker: Martin
text: Yeah, yeah.  It's rough for adults.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_almost crying_] Oh, Dad...

speaker: Martin
text: Merry Christmas, son.

speaker: Frasier
text: How did you know?  It's just what I always wanted: My very own Outlaw Laser Robo Geek.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, Dad - oh, oh, listen, are the batteries included?

speaker: Martin
text: In the box.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, Dad! [_hugs him again_]
